Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The People and Process of Federal Criminal Cases

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
A substantial proportion of Americans come into contact with a criminal trial court at some point in their lives. The process of adjudicating criminal cases asserts significant personal, financial, and social costs. This study will investigate the dynamic multi-stage process of the criminal case and what role courtroom professionals have in its development. Specifically, this study examines what influence judges, defense attorneys, and prosecutors have on the outcomes faced by the accused. In so doing, it hopes to offer findings that may improve the administration of justice in America.

This project will collect original data on the processing of federal criminal cases. It uses a stratified random sample of 9,200 cases of sentenced defendants from 23 federal district courts for 2006 to 2013. Specific areas of inquiry in the subsequent statistical analysis include whether a defendant is released or held in a detention facility pending trial, the amount of time it takes for each case to be adjudicated, and the severity of sentence imposed upon the convicted defendant. The study will consider how the backgrounds and preferences of judges, defense attorneys, and prosecutors impact these essential stages. The results will give key insights into trial court decision-making, which remains underexplored by much of the current research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ethan Boldt concluded his NSF DRIG supported dissertation project “The Process is the People: Judge and Attorney Influence in Federal Criminal Cases” and graduated in May of 2019. With the assistance of the grant, Boldt gathered, coded, and paired thousands of criminal cases with existing sources to create a novel dataset. Prior research into the impact of judges and attorneys on criminal cases has been limited by the exclusion of these courtroom professionals from data sources. This new resource, created by Boldt’s project, puts in sharp focus the role that judges and attorneys have in shaping what happens to defendants accused of federal crimes. The results reveal that political factors, the diversification of the judiciary, the type of defense counsel provided, and attorney qualifications meaningfully affect criminal case processes across multiple stages.

To create this resource, Boldt recruited and collaborated with talented University of Georgia undergraduate student research assistants employed under the NSF DRIG Grant. Court documents associated with criminal defendants were gathered from a random sample of cases within the federal district courts. Key events and people from these criminal cases were coded by Ethan Boldt and the assistants. In addition, the backgrounds and characteristics of the judges and attorneys involved in the case were extensively examined. Student research assistants gained valuable experience interacting with legal information and conducting social science research. Further, students were educated about the federal criminal court process. Several students used their grant-funded experiences to aid them in successfully applying to law school, graduate school, and law enforcement positions.

Using the data gathered for this project, Boldt conducted his dissertation analysis of the impact of attorneys and judges across three key criminal case indicators: time to disposition, bail, and sentencing. The results were produced in Boldt’s dissertation, which he plans to develop into peer-reviewed journal publications. Boldt’s analysis found several interesting results. Important disparities in sentencing arose from the ideology of individual judges, the judge’s gender, and the attributes of the defense counsel provided to the defendant. Pretrial detention was driven by many of the same factors. In regards to time to disposition, the length of a case was primarily shaped by the attorneys rather than individual judges. The results of this analysis make a meaningful contribution to an interdisciplinary literature, which has long been limited in studying the effects of judges and attorneys in criminal cases. Ethan Boldt’s dissertation renews claims by foundational social science studies of U.S. criminal courts that courtroom professionals have meaningful power and can affect what happens to defendants even when accounting for the law. These findings have clear application toward criminal justice reform which has garnered bipartisan interest. Boldt has disseminated his findings through presentations at academic conferences and at invited talks in departments of multiple academic disciplines.

For Ethan Boldt, this project provided an opportunity to develop key professional skills. From his positive experiences working with undergraduate students on research, Boldt built a strong foundation to continue mentoring students to pursue their curiosities and career goals. Using the skills built from this project, Boldt can continue to pursue large scale data collection efforts with confidence and conduct further studies of the U.S. justice system.
